Organic radical functionalized SBA-15 as a heterogeneous catalyst for facile oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-diformylfuran Neha Mittal Grace M. Nisola Jeong Gil Seo ⁎ Seong-Poong Lee Wook-Jin Chung Energy and Environment Fusion Technology Center (E2FTC), Department of Energy and Biotechnology (DEB), Myongji University, Myongji-ro 116, Namdong,Cheoingu, Yongin-city, Gyeonggi-Do 449-728, Republic of Korea Energy and Environment Fusion Technology Center (E2FTC) Department of Energy and Biotechnology (DEB) Myongji University Myongji-ro 116 Namdong Cheoingu Yongin-city Gyeonggi-Do 449-728 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 31 324 1338; fax: +82 31 336 6336. Graphical abstract Organic radical functionalized mesoporous silica was prepared by the immobilization of 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) on ordered mesoporous silica (SBA-15) and applied as a heterogeneous catalyst (TEMPO-SBA-15) for the synthesis of 2,5-diformylfuran (2,5-DFF) from 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF). A 73 % 2,5-DFF yield was obtained from 5-HMF oxidation under mild reaction conditions in ethyl acetate with the addition of [bis(acetoxy) iodo]benzene (BAIB) and acetic acid as co-oxidants in an oxygen-rich environment. The presence of BAIB and oxygen facilitated the in-situ regeneration of TEMPO (the hydroxylamine form) whereas acetic acid addition aided in the initial formation of oxoammonium form of TEMPO, which was responsible for facile 5-HMF oxidation. All reaction components were found critical in maximizing the 2,5-DFF yield. The pore size distribution and architecture of SBA-15 played essential roles for the diffusive transport of reactants and products and resulted in improved reaction selectivity. Aside from these advantages, TEMPO-SBA-15 catalyst was easily separated and re-used several times with negligible loss in its catalytic activity. The prepared heterogeneous TEMPO-SBA-15 is an efficient catalyst that offers a sustainable route for 2,5-DFF production. Keywords 2,5-Diformylfuran 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural 4-Hydroxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl Oxidation Immobilization Mesoporous silica 1 Introduction Furan derivatives are value-added chemicals that can be derived from biomass feedstocks. Particularly, 2,5-diformylfuran (2,5-DFF) is a commercially important precursor for the synthesis of various pharmaceuticals, fungicides, ligands of various poly-Schiff bases, polymers, and cross-linking agents [1–4]. 2,5-DFF is typically synthesized by selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) [5], a dehydration product of biomass-derived hexoses [5–7]. Many reports have been accounted for the oxidation of 5-HMF using conventional, metal containing homogeneous catalysts like Pb(OAc)4-pyridine, pyridinium chlorochromate, K2Cr2O7-DMSO, Co/Mn acetates, V2O5, and Cu(NO3)2/VOSO4 [8–13]. Although adequate 2,5-DFF yields have been reported, most of these catalysts are laden with toxic metals. Moreover, many of the reported 2,5-DFF syntheses are conducted under severe reaction conditions (≥80°C and ≥10bar) with several hours of reaction time. This increases the cost of production set-up and in few cases leads to side products formation by over-oxidation, decarbonylation, and cross-polymerization of 5-HMF [13]. Parallel to the need of cheap, easily handled and less toxic catalytic system, a re-usable oxidation catalyst is also highly desirable to ease environmental and economic burdens. Several heterogeneous catalytic systems likewise have been employed for the oxidation of 5-HMF such as vanadyl phosphate [14], vanadyl acetylacetonate immobilized on poly(4-vinylpyridine) polymer [15], Ru supported over hydrotalcite [16], porous manganese oxide [17], zeolite-supported vanadium pentoxide [18] and silver impregnated manganese oxide [19]. Despite the remarkable developments in 2,5-DFF synthesis with fair yield, nearly all these systems are based on transition metal catalysts and high boiling point organic solvents which hinder the facile product separation [14–19]. Moreover, the active sites in these catalysts were transition metals, requiring higher activation energy to perform and thus these systems were applied at higher reaction temperature. In context of a metal-free catalyst, nitroxyl based radicals are being explored due to their efficiency in oxidizing various types of alcohols [20–22]. In addition, these have shown less toxicity and remarkable reversible redox behavior [21–24]. One of these stable organic radicals, 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-oxyl (TEMPO) and its derivatives have been used for 5-HMF oxidation in the presence of various co-oxidants [25–27]. Particularly, an earlier work successfully produced 2,5-DFF under mild reaction conditions via homogeneous TEMPO-catalyzed 5-HMF oxidation with co-oxidants [bis(acetoxy)iodo]benzene (BAIB) and acetic acid (AcOH) [27]. Despite the satisfactory formation of 2,5-DFF, this mild homogeneous reaction could not address the catalyst recyclability and high reaction selectivity due to formation of side product. Thus, the TEMPO moiety immobilized on an appropriate solid support can provide an effective, sustainable, and metal free catalytic system. Several supported TEMPO catalyst systems like on silica and ferrite surface [28], carbon nanotubes [29] and mesoporous silica [30] have been reported for the oxidation of alcohols. However, these catalyst systems were comprised of either transition metals [28] or toxic and hazardous reagents like tert-butyl nitrite (TBN) [30]. Recently oxidation of 5-HMF by TEMPO supported on silica coated iron oxide nanoparticles was demonstrated [31]. But the use of nocuous TBN and high boiling point solvent toluene with hours long reaction time makes this methodology inappropriate from the viewpoint of green and sustainable chemistry. Therefore, our continuous interest is in developing a less toxic reaction system for 5-HMF oxidation in low boiling point solvents [27]. Among various support materials for catalysts, the suitability of mesoporous silica like SBA-15 has been demonstrated in numerous studies, as the silanol groups on their surfaces are easy to functionalize [32]. The stability of TEMPO can be assured by its covalent immobilization on the support through organosilane linkers. The unique structural properties of mesoporous SBA-15 like a high specific surface area due to its well-ordered porous structure, large pore volumes, and narrow pore size distribution (Fig. 1 B, inset), would allow a high degree of TEMPO functionalization leading toward an efficient heterogeneous TEMPO catalyst. Thus, herein, TEMPO-functionalized-SBA-15 (TEMPO-SBA-15) catalyst was prepared through silanization of TEMPO radicals functionalized with an organosilane linker. Morphological and structural properties of bare SBA-15 and its functionalized form (TEMPO-SBA-15) were examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), FT-IR, and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Comparisons in their characterization results were performed to confirm the successful immobilization of TEMPO on SBA-15. The prepared TEMPO-SBA-15 was applied as heterogeneous catalyst for the oxidation of 5-HMF to 2,5-DFF under mild reaction conditions. For maximum 2,5-DFF yields, effects of co-oxidants were also determined. Lastly, the long-term use of TEMPO-SBA-15 was also inspected through a series of repeated 5-HMF oxidation reactions using recycled catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 4-Hydroxy-TEMPO (97 %), BAIB (98 %), organosilane linker (3-chloropropyl)-triethoxysilane (CPTES) (95 %), poly(ethyleneglycol)-block-poly(propyleneglycol)-block-poly(ethyleneglycol) (Pluronic®P123), silica (fumed, surface area 390m2/g) and dry toluene (99.8 %) were obtained from Sigma–Aldrich (South Korea). 5-Hydroxymethylfufural (5-HMF) (98 %), tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) (98 %), sodium hydride (NaH) (60 % dispersion in oil), and dry tetrahydrofuran (THF) (99.8 %) were purchased from Acros Organics while 2,5-diformylfuran (2,5-DFF) (>98 %) was procured from Tokyo Chemicals (Japan). Hydrochloric acid (HCl) (35-37 %) was bought from Showa Chemicals whereas other solvents including diethyl ether (99 %) and ethyl acetate (99.8 %) were obtained from Dae Jung Chemicals (South Korea). Sodium sulfate (99 %) was purchased from Junsei Chemicals. All chemicals were of reagent grade or higher, and were directly used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalyst 2.2.1 Preparation of SBA-15 SBA-15 was synthesized according to a modified method reported elsewhere using tri-block copolymer Pluronic®P123 (average mol. weight=5800) as a structure directing agent [33]. A 10g sample of P123 was initially dissolved in a mixture of 325mL of deionized (DI) water and 60mL of HCl (35.0-37.0 %) followed by TEOS (20.6g) addition, with 800rpm agitation, at 40°C for 2h. The cloudy dispersion was then statically aged at 40°C for 24h and then at 80°C for another 24h. The solid product was filtered off; repeatedly washed with hot (80°C) deionized (DI) water for the removal of residual reactants. After air-drying at room temperature for 4 days, the dried powder was calcined at 500°C (in air, 5h) with 2.5°C/min heating rate from room temperature. 2.2.2 Synthesis of 3-(4-oxy-TEMPO)propyl-triethoxysilane The reactions were carried out in nitrogen (N2) atmosphere. Sodium hydride (0.2758g, 6.9mmol) was suspended in dry THF (20mL) cooled in an ice-bath. A separately prepared 4-hydroxy-TEMPO (1.0g, 5.8mmol) solution in 5mL dry THF was added dropwise in the cold NaH slurry. The mixture was brought to room temperature (RT) and stirred to facilitate the reaction. After complete gas evolution, the mixture was re-cooled at 0°C and CPTES (1.6615g, 6.9mmol) was added dropwise. The reaction was continued at room temperature for another 48h (Scheme 1 ). The crude product was retrieved by solvent evaporation under reduced pressure. To precipitate the impurities, the oily product was dissolved in diethyl ether. The filtered diethyl ether was dried over sodium sulfateand then re-filtered. The solvent was removed in a rotary evaporator to obtain the pure dark oily orange 3-(4-oxy-TEMPO)propyl-triethoxysilane (denoted as PTES-TEMPO). 2.2.3 Preparation of TEMPO-SBA-15 catalyst Calcined SBA-15 (2.0g) was vacuum-dried for 1h at 90°C and then suspended in 90mL dry toluene with vigorous stirring under N2 atmosphere. A solution of PTES-TEMPO (1.53mmol) in toluene was then added dropwise in the SBA-15 suspension. The mixture was refluxed at 110°C for 20h with continuous stirring (Scheme 1). After which, the reaction was terminated and cooled to room temperature. The product, denoted as TEMPO-SBA-15, was filtered, washed three times with toluene, and then dried in air at room temperature. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Powder low angle X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of SBA-15 and TEMPO-SBA-15 samples were acquired using PANalytical EMPYREAN SWAX diffractometer (40kV, 25mA) with Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation (λ =0.15406nm) source scanned at 2θ angles from 0.3° to 10°. The FT-IR spectra of the samples were recorded by a Shimadzu IRPrestige-21 spectrophotometer equipped with DLaTGS detector using standard KBr disc method (1wt.% sample) between wavenumbers 400 and 4000cm−1 at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in a SCINCO TGA (N-1000) from 35°C to 1000°C with a ramping rate of 5°C/min, supplied with 50mL/min of N2. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained using a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 surface area analyzer at 195.8°C. The samples were outgassed (in vacuum) at 100°C for 24h prior to the adsorption experiments. The carbon and nitrogen contents of the samples were determined by element analysis using Vario EL cube CHNS analyzer (Elementar Corporation, Germany). The morphology of the samples was observed under Hitachi S-3500N Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) and JEOL JSM-7600F Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FE-SEM). 2.4 Catalyst activity 2.4.1 Typical procedure for the synthesis of 2,5-DFF from 5-HMF All experiments were carried out in two-necked round bottom flasks initially purged with O2 and then fastened with an O2-filled balloon (1atm). The flasks were placed in a temperature-controlled oil bath with magnetic stirring. Typically, appropriate amounts of the reactants 5-HMF, TEMPO-SBA-15, BAIB, and acetic acid (if used) were allowed to react in ethyl acetate solvent (10-15mL). The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred for a certain reaction time, at a controlled temperature. After each run, the reaction mixture was filtered to separate the solid catalyst. The filtrate was dried under reduced pressure, dissolved in deionized (DI) water and then analyzed in high pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC). 2.5 Product analysis and quantification Prior to HPLC analysis, samples were filtered through a syringe filter (0.2μm Nylon). The Waters HPLC was equipped with Waters 2414 refractive index (RI) detector maintained at 40°C and Biorad Aminex HPX-87H ion-exclusion column (300×7.8mm) kept at 60°C. A 5mM H2SO4 mobile phase was delivered at a flow rate of 0.6mL/min. The HPLC retention times for reaction components were observed as 14.7min for AcOH, 14.7min for 2,5-FDCA, 28.0min for 5-HMF and 32.7min for 2,5-DFF. The concentrations of 2,5-DFF (i.e., [DFF]) and 5-HMF (i.e., [HMF]) were determined against calibration curves of standard samples. The amount of produced 2,5-DFF (W DFF) and corresponding reaction yields were calculated according to Eqs. (1) and (2). 2,5-DFF selectivity was calculated according to Eq. S1. V is the sample volume, MW is the molecular weight of 5-HMF (126.11g/mol) or 2,5-DFF (124.09g/mol) while W RM, W AL, and W HMF are the masses of the entire reaction mixture, aliquot for analysis and supplied 5-HMF, respectively. All reported data are average values of triplicate reaction runs. (1) W DFF ( mg ) = [ DFF ] × V ( mL ) × W RM ( mg ) W AL ( mg ) (2) DFF yield ( % ) = ( W DFF W HMF ) ( M W HMF M W DFF ) × 100 2.6 Recycling of the catalyst After oxidation reaction, TEMPO-SBA-15 was retrieved from the reaction mixture via filtration. The used catalyst was washed with the reaction solvent to remove traces of reaction debris. Then the catalyst was air-dried at room temperature prior to reuse. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of catalyst The mesoporous silica support SBA-15 was prepared through TEOS hydrolysis in the presence of the triblock co-polymer P123 (EO20PO70EO20) as the surfactant [33]. Meanwhile in a separate reaction, TEMPO was etherified with CPTES to form PTES-TEMPO. To complete the synthesis of TEMPO-SBA-15, PTES-TEMPO was used to silanize the support, in which covalent SiOSi bonds were formed by the reaction of silanol groups on SBA-15 with the ethoxy groups of PTES-TEMPO (Scheme 1). 3.2 Characterization of catalyst Textural properties of SBA-15 were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 1). The bare support material (SBA-15) exhibited three well-resolved diffraction peaks at 2θ =0.9°, 1.5°, and 1.7° in the XRD pattern (Fig. 1A), which correspond to reflection planes of (100), (110), and (200), respectively. These peaks indicate a significant degree of long-range order and a well-formed two-dimensional (2-D) hexagonal meso-structure of SBA-15 [34]. After immobilization, the resulting TEMPO-SBA-15 exhibited all of the prominent diffraction peaks at 2θ =0.9°, 1.5°, and 1.7° (Fig. 1A) similar to SBA-15. This implies that the 2-D hexagonal meso-structure of SBA-15 does not deteriorate after the immobilization of PTES-TEMPO. Thus, prepared TEMPO-SBA-15 demonstrated analogous reflection planes to its support material, suggesting that the periodic mesoporous structure was retained [35]. Furthermore, the decrease in intensity of diffraction peak corresponding to reflection plane of (100) confirms the successful immobilization of PTES-TEMPO to SBA-15 surface. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms obtained from bare SBA-15 exhibits the typical type IV isotherm pattern having sharp capillary condensation with H1 hysteresis loop at higher relative pressure (Fig. 1B). This pertains to the 2-D hexagonal symmetry of a mesoporous material [36–37]. TEMPO-SBA-15 showed similar adsorption-desorption isotherm curves and hysteresis loop with that of bare SBA-15. In addition, both SBA-15 and TEMPO-SBA-15 showed narrow pore size distributions (Fig. 1B, inset), indicating structural consistency of the catalyst before and after immobilization. The bare SBA-15 showed a very high BET surface area of 883m2/g (Table 1 ) and large total pore volume of 1.24cm3/g (Table 1). The gradual decrease in BET surface area and total pore volume upon immobilization of PTES-TEMPO confirms its successful immobilization to the pore channels of SBA-15. Nonetheless, incorporation of TEMPO on SBA-15 did not reduce the average pore size of the support due to simultaneous functionalization in micro- and meso-pores which counterbalances the changes in pore size. Thus, kept intact the mesoporous structure of the support material even after functionalization. The TG analyses of the heterogeneous catalyst and SBA-15 were done to assess the functionalization of TEMPO on SBA-15 and to estimate the loading of TEMPO radical (Fig. 2 ). The first weight losses (<2 %) in bare SBA-15 and TEMPO-SBA-15 were observed below 100°C, due to the evaporation of surface-adsorbed moisture. Further weight loss up to 8.58 % was observed in TEMPO-SBA-15 from 110 to 235°C with a sharp decrease around 156°C, due to the degradation of the 3-(4-oxy-TEMPO)propyl chain on the SBA-15 surface [38]. This result indicated the loss of 0.4mmol of 3-(4-oxy-TEMPO)propyl chain per gram of the catalyst material, from which, 0.3mmol/g loading of TEMPO was estimated. Without the functional groups on the bare support, such weight loss was absent in SBA-15 within the same temperature range. Only 3.21 % total weight loss was observed for bare SBA-15, mainly due to the condensation of surface silanols that forms siloxane groups and release of water molecules at higher temperatures (>600°C) [39]. For TEMPO-SBA-15, the significant weight loss of 16.68 % between 235 and 1000°C is associated to the breakdown of the unreacted ethoxy groups of the organosilane and partially to the silanol condensation. Elemental analysis also determined the loading of TEMPO as 0.3mmol/g of TEMPO-SBA-15 (Table 1) along with 15.7 C/N ratio, which strongly corroborates the TGA result. The successful immobilization of the TEMPO on SBA-15 was further confirmed via the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 3 ). The IR spectrum of PTES-TEMPO (Fig. 3a) features characteristic absorption bands at 1373 and 1165 cm−1 for the CN and CO stretching vibrations, respectively [29]. Additionally, the spectrum presents peaks in the range of 2995-2870cm−1 associated with CH stretching vibrations. Characteristic bands of the silica frameworks were observed both in bare SBA-15 and TEMPO-SBA-15 (Fig. 3b and c); at 3600-3200cm−1 for stretching of H-bonded silanol groups, at 1085 and 806cm−1for asymmetric and symmetric SiOSi stretching and at 964cm−1 for SiO stretching [40]. The absorption peak at 1629cm−1 is associated with the bending vibration of the adsorbed water [41]. In the heterogeneous catalyst, a CN stretching vibration was present (Fig. 3c) at 1377cm−1, which asserts the presence of TEMPO moiety. The wide band of SiOSi stretching (albeit it overlapped the CO stretching) concomitant with the decrease in the peak intensities of (1) OH stretching and bending (3600-3200cm−1 and 1629cm−1, respectively) and (2) SiO stretching (964cm−1) are all indications of a successful silanization of PTES-TEMPO on SBA-15. The morphologies of bare SBA-15 and TEMPO-SBA-15 were examined by SEM as shown in Fig. 4 . The mesoporous SBA-15 features a long-range, self-organized morphology and uniform-sized particles which were preserved after PTES-TEMPO immobilization (Fig. 4a and b). Both samples were composed of rod like, bean-shaped particles of approximately 800-1000nm in length. The FE-SEM images of SBA-15 and TEMPO-SBA-15 (Fig. 4c and d, respectively) (100nm scale) also showed well-ordered arrays of mesoporous channels [42] and intact morphology of SBA-15 after immobilization of TEMPO. 3.3 Homogeneous TEMPO-catalyzed 5-HMF oxidation In an earlier work, homogeneous TEMPO-mediated oxidation of 5-HMF in ethyl acetate afforded 2,5-DFF through the ‘oxoammonium’ mechanism [18]. Concomitant with 5-HMF oxidation into 2,5-DFF is the in-situ reduction of the oxoammonium form of TEMPO into hydroxylamine form. As a regenerant, co-oxidant BAIB is added to oxidize hydroxylamine back to TEMPO radical form and it also produces acetic acid for the initial dismutation of TEMPO radical to its catalytically active oxoammoinum form [27]. Thus, 2,5-DFF production in catalytic TEMPO dosage was possible in the presence of BAIB. For enhanced 2,5-DFF yield, initial investigation was performed in a homogeneous system of 5-HMF (0.5mmol) and BAIB (0.75mmol) with varied TEMPO dosages. Production of 2,5-DFF (Fig. 5 ) increased with the catalyst dosage and the highest values were obtained at over 0.075mmol of TEMPO. The high conversion of 5-HMF at lower TEMPO dosages is the result of ligand exchange phenomenon with BAIB (Fig. S4). Due to inadequate TEMPO, yield of 2,5-DFF remained less. Nonetheless, only moderate 2,5-DFF yield (57.4 % maximum at 0.1 mmol TEMPO dosage) was achieved in homogeneous TEMPO-catalyzed system. Meanwhile, homogeneous TEMPO-catalyzed reactions in oxygen-rich condition afforded much higher 2,5-DFF yields and selectivities at entire range of TEMPO dosages than the system in the absence of oxygen (Fig. 5 and Fig. S3). Molecular oxygen (O2) functions similarly as BAIB by oxidizing the hydroxylamine form of TEMPO catalyst to its radical form as demonstrated by Dijksman et al. [43] (Fig. S4). Furthermore, the effect of oxygen and phenomenon of ligand exchange involving 5-HMF and BAIB were validated by only 9.8 % 5-HMF conversion and 5.2 % 2,5-DFF yield by the BAIB-free system with oxygen supply (Fig. 7 ). Additionally, despite the high 2,5-DFF yield in O2-rich homogeneous system, a minor amount of 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (2,5-FDCA), an over-oxidation product of 5-HMF [19], was also observed (Fig. S1). 3.4 5-HMF oxidation in heterogeneous TEMPO-SBA-15 catalyst With enhanced 2,5 DFF productions in O2-rich TEMPO-catalyzed homogeneous system, heterogeneous reactions were likewise performed over TEMPO-SBA-15 catalyst (Scheme 2 ). Highest yield of 52 % 2,5-DFF was achieved (Fig. 5) with heterogeneous TEMPO (at 0.075mmol of TEMPO) (Fig. S4). Unlike homogeneous system, no 2,5-FDCA was detected in heterogeneous TEMPO-SBA-15 catalyst system (Fig. S2) resulting in enhanced reaction selectivity by controlled conversion of 5-HMF to dialdehyde (Fig. S3). In the context of slightly declined 2,5-DFF production and no 2,5-FDCA formation by TEMPO-SBA-15 (i.e., compared to homogeneous TEMPO-catalyzed reaction), immobilization of TEMPO moieties into the porous channels of SBA-15 played a crucial role. These results suggest the critical role of SBA-15 as TEMPO support. The highly ordered and uniform porous structure of SBA-15 leads to form uniform active sites of the TEMPO catalyst and also controls the spatial effects. These factors are crucial for the diffusive transport of reactants to and products from active sites and, thereby controlling the over-oxidation of product. 3.5 Influence of reaction temperature on TEMPO-SBA-15 performance The effect of reaction temperature was also investigated to attain better 2,5-DFF production. As the reaction components have reduced diffusive transport in heterogeneous catalyst systems, heating the reaction could increase their kinetic mobility and improve their contact frequency with active sites of catalyst. This effect became modestly observable when the temperature was slightly raised to 40°C as the maximum 2,5-DFF yield improved to 63 % (Fig. 6 ) from 52 % (at RT) with complete 5-HMF conversion (Table S1) in 60min. Additionally, oxidation of 5-HMF followed consecutive conversion into two intermediate states; first by rapid ligand exchange with BAIB (Fig. S4a) and then, reaction with oxoammonium salt (+NO) form of TEMPO radical moiety (Fig. S4b). The formation of 2,5-DFF occurred simultaneously with the reduction of oxoammonium salt to hydroxylamine form. Therefore, the production of 2,5-DFF was lagging behind as compared to the quick consumption of 5-HMF. As a consequence, high 5-HMF conversion with low 2,5-DFF selectivity was observed in initial stages of the reaction at low reaction temperature. While the rate of 2,5-DFF formation increased with reaction temperature, the declines in 2,5-DFF yields were observed under prolonged reaction periods at all temperatures. This is attributable to eventual degradation of 2,5-DFF to other undetected compounds [11]. Though the maximum 2,5-DFF formation (57 %) at 50°C was quickly reached within 30-45min, the reduced 2,5-DFF selectivity (Table S1) might have been due to the additional occurrence of 5-HMF degradation at elevated temperatures [44]. In a previous work, the uninhibited exposure of homogeneous TEMPO to the substrate resulted in the higher propensity of the reaction components to degradation. Increase in temperature beyond ambient condition was detrimental to selective 2,5-DFF production [27]. In the current study, however, the insulating effect of SBA-15 on TEMPO was beneficial as it rendered TEMPO-SBA-15 to perform more efficiently in a wider temperature range. From the results, reaction at 40°C for 60min was most appropriate to enhance 2,5-DFF yield with minimal degradation of reaction components. 3.6 Acetic acid addition for enhanced TEMPO-SBA-15 performance To initiate 5-HMF oxidation, the TEMPO radicals immobilized on SBA-15 must be dismutated to its oxoammonium form in the presence of acetic acid (AcOH) [20] (Fig. S4). Previous work identified the dual role of BAIB as TEMPO regenerant and as AcOH source (via ligand exchange), which was needed to ‘jump-start’ the oxidation reaction by formation of oxoammonium. However, participation of BAIB in ligand exchange reaction with 5-HMF to form AcOH was only minor, prompting the necessity of external AcOH addition [27]. Results (Fig. 7 and Table S2) confirmed that addition of small amount of AcOH (0.05mmol) remarkably increased the 2,5-DFF yields of both homogeneous (78 %) and heterogeneous TEMPO-catalyzed systems (73 %). The small difference in 2,5-DFF yields between the homogeneous and heterogeneous systems further affirms the benefit of using SBA-15 as the support material for TEMPO. The catalyst support SBA-15 exerted minimum effect on the TEMPO due to uniform distribution of active sites in its mesoporous structure. Moreover, the suitable organosilane linker (CPTES) aids to TEMPO moiety with its propyl chain by providing enough space to react by lessening any steric hindrance in the vicinity. Thus, TEMPO-SBA-15 closely mimicked the behavior of the homogeneous catalyst system [45] in terms of 2,5-DFF yield. A similar heterogeneous catalyst TEMPO-Silica using silica (fumed) (TEMPO loading 0.1 mmol/g) was compared for 5-HMF oxidation resulting into 42 % 2,5-DFF yield (Fig. 7) with complete 5-HMF conversion (Table S2). The possible reason could be the lesser exposure to active sites due to aggregation of silica particles and the decreased diffusive transport of reaction components unlike in the TEMPO-SBA-15. 3.7 Stability and recycling of TEMPO-SBA-15 The stability of TEMPO-SBA-15 was examined by repeated use of the catalyst in the same reaction conditions. Recovered TEMPO-SBA-15 had similar catalytic performance with that of a fresh catalyst even after several recycling runs (Fig. 8 e). The 2,5-DFF yields were maintained above 71 % with minimal variation between each cycle. After five consecutive cycles, TEMPO-SBA-15 did not reveal any noteworthy form of chemical and structural deterioration as evidenced by FT-IR and SEM analyses, respectively (Fig. 8a–d). Recycling tests confirm the potential of TEMPO-SBA-15 for long term repeated use as a catalyst for 5-HMF oxidation to 2,5-DFF. 4 Conclusion The TEMPO catalyst with organosilane linker was successfully immobilized on SBA-15 support via silanization as confirmed by various characterization techniques. This metal-free heterogeneous catalyst presented promising results by providing high 2,5-DFF yield in short reaction time at ambient reaction conditions as compared to previously reported reaction systems. The mesoporous SBA-15 proved suitable as support of TEMPO; there was minimal reduction in 2,5-DFF yields and low propensity of the products and substrates for unwanted product formation. Thus, heterogeneous TEMPO-SBA-15 catalyst provides an effective route for 2,5-DFF production, with reliable catalytic activity for repeated and long-term use. coredata.dc:description: Organic radical functionalized mesoporous silica was prepared by the immobilization of 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) on ordered mesoporous silica (SBA-15) and applied as a heterogeneous catalyst (TEMPO-SBA-15) for the synthesis of 2,5-diformylfuran (2,5-DFF) from 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF). A 73 % 2,5-DFF yield was obtained from 5-HMF oxidation under mild reaction conditions in ethyl acetate with the addition of [bis(acetoxy) iodo]benzene (BAIB) and acetic acid as co-oxidants in an oxygen-rich environment. The presence of BAIB and oxygen facilitated the in-situ regeneration of TEMPO (the hydroxylamine form) whereas acetic acid addition aided in the initial formation of oxoammonium form of TEMPO, which was responsible for facile 5-HMF oxidation. All reaction components were found critical in maximizing the 2,5-DFF yield. The pore size distribution and architecture of SBA-15 played essential roles for the diffusive transport of reactants and products and resulted in improved reaction selectivity. Aside from these advantages, TEMPO-SBA-15 catalyst was easily separated and re-used several times with negligible loss in its catalytic activity. The prepared heterogeneous TEMPO-SBA-15 is an efficient catalyst that offers a sustainable route for 2,5-DFF production.
coredata.dc:title: Organic radical functionalized SBA-15 as a heterogeneous catalyst for facile oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-diformylfuran
